results.title: In heaven there is no beer
results.creator_credit: Les Blank, Maureen Gosling and Flower Films
results.brief_description: This film visits a number of intensive polka sessions (one of them an 11-day marathon) and observes the wildly enthusiastic participants. The film also examines the dancers’ Polish patriotism and their polka regalia, concluding that they may find a close and authentic sense of community through this form of folk art.

results.title: In good company
results.brief_description: A recruiting film made to encourage young men to join the Army as officers. Shows the Officers Training School at Portsea in Victoria, the Royal Military College at Duntroon in Canberra and gives an insight into the lifestyle and career opportunities offered by the Army to any young man who wishes both to further his education at a tertiary level as well as seek a challenging and rewarding career as an officer in the Australian Army.

results.title: In God's command
results.creator_credit: Garth Pritchard, Graydon McCrea, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Throughout the history of war there has been the silent presence of the army chaplain, a comforting person in the midst of atrocities, offering spiritual support and material comfort. ‘In God’s command’ offers an intimate portrait of one such chaplain, Captain Mark Sargent, army officer, Roman Catholic priest and chaplain to the soldiers of the First Battalion; Princess Patricia’s Canadian light infantry, stationed in the former Yugoslavia. The viewer follows Sargent as he ministers soldiers and civilians, arranging Mass, celebrating a baptism, and performs other priestly duties under the most trying conditions with conviction, compassion and humor. Narrated by military historian Gywnne Dyer.

results.title: In fear of every dawn [Magnetic soundtrack]
results.brief_description: Western propaganda presenting life on the Eastern side of the ‘Berlin Wall’. Filmed from the Western side of the border, the film records activities on the Eastern side and provides an anti-communist interpretation and commentary. Shows locals carrying out daily activities; armed guards patrolling the border; watch-towers and concealed observation areas; propaganda billboards; ‘indoctrinated’ youths recruited as guards and frontier police; the ‘forcible’ removal of families from their ancestral homes into detention centres; and endless footage of barbed wire and uniformed personnel.

results.title: In cold blood : the massacre of East Timor
results.creator_credit: Max Stahl, Peter Gordon and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: Produced originally as a segment for the Yorkshire Television program “First Tuesday”. The Island of East Timor was annexed by Indonesia in 1975 and has suffered military occupation ever since. In 1991 troops opened fire on a funeral procession in Dili - the bloody massacre that ensued was captured on film by a Yorkshire Television camaraman and became headline news around the world. That footage is backed up in this documentary by frank and moving interviews with Timorese who describe the succession of atrocities inflicted on them dating back to 1975.

results.title: In case of fire. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Stresses that heat, smoke and poisonous gases are the elements that can kill in a fire. Outlines ways in which to avoid fire hazards in the home. Shows what to do should a fire break out in the house or apartment building when occupied.

results.title: In Between. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Chris Dalton, Mandy Smith, Chris Warner and Kim Dalton
results.brief_description: Two episodes of “In Between” a series of dramas set in Melbourne that looks at the pressures of growing up. Episode One is about Fatima who wants to be a journalist. However, her father believes that Fatima should leave school and return to Turkey to an arranged marriage. Episode Two is about Saret who is an illegal immigrant from Cambodia.

results.title: In a fishing port
results.creator_credit: Frank L. Few, Jean Richards, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Shows a few days in the life of a daughter of a Port Franklin flounder fisherman, showing her at school, horse riding in the bush and helping her father in his fishing boat to lay nets and sort, clean and pack the fish.
Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Imran Khan
results.creator_credit: John E. Bodnar and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Imran Khan, the Tiger of Pakistan, was born into a famous cricketing family and became the most inspirational cricketer of his generation. From his early days at Oxford to his full test career with Pakistan, he has experienced unparralleled success as a genuine all-rounder. His test career, spanning three decades, has seen him develop from a precocious talent to a father-like figure exuding respect and experience. Features highlights of his playing career including his many records and achievements.

results.title: Impunidad
results.creator_credit: Helen Gaynor, Cam Productions, Film Victoria and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Impunidad, impunity n. “exemption from punishment”. In 1954 a CIA-backed military coup toppled the democratic government in Guatemala allowing full control by the Army over the citizens of Guatemala. During the 1960’s and 1970’s a guerilla movement established itself throughout large areas of the country-side, and in the late 70’s the Army took on a “scorched earth policy” destroying 440 villages, with 100,000 civilians murdered and 45,000 missing. In a land shrouded in silence where 2.1% of the population own 72% of arable land, 86% live in poverty and 1,000,000 are internally displaced, Australian filmmaker, Helen Gaynor, worked undercover to reveal the continuing violence between the armed forces and the indigenous peoples, the terror and corruption which still allows the army to continue acting with impunity. 65% of the 10 million population are indigenous Mayan Indians, and despite 500 years of oppression, many facets of their culture survives. Though fewer in number, the disappearances, torture and massacres are still occurring today. Narrated by Jenny Seedsman In English and Spanish with English subtitles.
